<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 304, 233]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics 1 (M1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 593, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 527, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 557, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 573, 756, 589]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 606, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 82, 662, 189]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 205, 920, 272]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string. The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(X\). A horizontal force of magnitude \(F \mathrm{N}\) is applied to the particle, which is in equilibrium when the string is at an angle \(\alpha\) to the vertical, where \(\tan \alpha = \frac{8}{15}\) (see diagram). Find the tension in the string and the value of \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 255, 920, 273]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 300, 92, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 310, 616, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 464, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
A block \(B\) lies on a rough horizontal plane. Horizontal forces of magnitudes \(30 \mathrm{N}\) and \(40 \mathrm{N}\), making angles of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) respectively with the \(x\)-direction, act on \(B\) as shown in the diagram, and \(B\) is moving in the \(x\)-direction with constant speed. It is given that \(\cos \alpha = 0.6\) and \(\cos \beta = 0.8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 528, 153, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 527, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Find the total work done by the forces shown in the diagram when \(B\) has moved a distance of \(20 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 574, 153, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 573, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
Given that the coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is \(\frac{5}{8}\), find the weight of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 592, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 636, 94, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 635, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
A cyclist exerts a constant driving force of magnitude \(F \mathrm{N}\) while moving up a straight hill inclined at an angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, where \(\sin \alpha = \frac{3}{45 \mathrm{s}}\). A constant resistance to motion of \(32 \mathrm{N}\) acts on the cyclist. The total weight of the cyclist and his bicycle is \(780 \mathrm{N}\). The cyclist's acceleration is \(-0.2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 718, 153, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 718, 320, 736]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 718, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 749, 547, 768]]<|/det|>
The cyclist's speed is \(7 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) at the bottom of the hill.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 781, 153, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 780, 670, 798]]<|/det|>
Find how far up the hill the cyclist travels before coming to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 781, 920, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Particles \(P\) and \(Q\) are moving in a straight line on a rough horizontal plane. The frictional forces are the only horizontal forces acting on the particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the deceleration of each of the particles given that the coefficient of friction between \(P\) and the plane is 0.2, and between \(Q\) and the plane is 0.25.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
At a certain instant, \(P\) passes through the point \(A\) and \(Q\) passes through the point \(B\). The distance \(AB\) is \(5 \mathrm{~m}\). The velocities of \(P\) and \(Q\) at \(A\) and \(B\) are \(8 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) and \(3 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\), respectively, both in the direction \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 230, 153, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 641, 247]]<|/det|>
Find the speeds of \(P\) and \(Q\) immediately before they collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 276, 96, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 920, 326]]<|/det|>
A lorry of mass \(15 000\mathrm{kg}\) climbs from the bottom to the top of a straight hill, of length \(1440\mathrm{m}\), at a constant speed of \(15\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). The top of the hill is \(16\mathrm{m}\) above the level of the bottom of the hill. The resistance to motion is constant and equal to \(1800\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 339, 156, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 339, 484, 357]]<|/det|>
Find the work done by the driving force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 369, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
On reaching the top of the hill the lorry continues on a straight horizontal road and passes through a point \(P\) with speed \(24 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). The resistance to motion is constant and is now equal to \(1600 \mathrm{~N}\). The work done by the lorry's engine from the top of the hill to the point \(P\) is \(5030 \mathrm{kJ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 433, 153, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 432, 601, 451]]<|/det|>
Find the distance from the top of the hill to the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 433, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 96, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 490, 641, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 688, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
Particles \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(0.3 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(0.7 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley. \(A\) is held at rest and \(B\) hangs freely, with both straight parts of the string vertical and both particles at a height of \(0.52 \mathrm{~m}\) above the floor (see diagram). \(A\) is released and both particles start to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 765, 153, 783]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 765, 395, 783]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 797, 685, 815]]<|/det|>
When both particles are moving with speed \(1.6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) the string breaks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 828, 153, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 828, 818, 846]]<|/det|>
Find the time taken, from the instant that the string breaks, for \(A\) to reach the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 828, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[328, 875, 670, 894]]<|/det|>
**[Question 7 is printed on the next page.]**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) starts from rest at a point \(O\) and moves in a straight line. \(P\) has acceleration \(0.6t \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\) at time \(t\) seconds after leaving \(O\), until \(t = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 648, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity and displacement from \(O\) of \(P\) when \(t = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 918, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 732, 170]]<|/det|>
After \(t = 10\), \(P\) has acceleration \(-0.4t \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\) until it comes to rest at a point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 184, 153, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 184, 336, 201]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(OA\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]
